item.title: Final Exam Review
item.description: There are some exam review materials on Moodle (a practice exam and solutions). The Wednesday class session will be a time to go over any questions you have.
item.content:encoded:
There are some exam review materials on Moodle (a practice exam and solutions). The Wednesday class session will be a time to go over any questions you have.

Here is the video (and DyKnow) from the section A review session.

item.title: Computability
item.description: Read about Computability and the Halting Problem. This is advanced material that will not be tested in this class, but it is worth seeing as the culmination of the language and computation models we have been exploring.
item.content:encoded:
Read about Computability and the Halting Problem. This is advanced material that will not be tested in this class, but it is worth seeing as the culmination of the language and computation models we have been exploring.

If you are interested, there is also related material on the Lambda Calculus, which relates Turing Machines back to functional programming.

item.title: Turing Machines
item.description: Read about General Grammars and Turing Machines. This is advanced material that will not be tested in this class, but it is worth seeing as the culmination of the language and computation models we have been exploring.
item.content:encoded:
Read about General Grammars and Turing Machines. This is advanced material that will not be tested in this class, but it is worth seeing as the culmination of the language and computation models we have been exploring.

Here is the video (and DyKnow) from the section A class session.

item.description: Read about parsing and pushdown automata, and look at the exercises in those sections.
item.content:encoded:
Read about parsing and pushdown automata, and look at the exercises in those sections.

Here is the video (and DyKnow) from the section A class session.

If you are interested in seeing actual parsing code, look at the section on recursive descent and parser combinators (and if you are really interested, take CSC 426, Compilers in the fall…).

Here is the video and DyKnow from the section A class session.

(Optional) The paper by E.F. Moore I mention in the first video is:

Moore, Edward F (1956). "Gedanken-experiments on Sequential Machines". Automata Studies, Annals of Mathematical Studies. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press (34): 129–153.

You can read it on the Internet Archive here.

item.title: Class Resumes
item.description: Classes will resume in an online format on Monday, March 30. Work on your DPoodle drawings.
item.content:encoded:
Classes will resume in an online format on Monday, March 30. Work on your DPoodle drawings.

Update Also read about trees and watch the corresponding video (and DyKnow).

Here are the videos and DyKnow slides from the in-class sessions:

  • Section A video and DyKnow
  • Section B video and DyKnow

My plan for now is ...

  • Lecture videos will be posted on this blog along with each day's reading. I hope to be able to do this a day or two in advance.
  • Class sessions conducted over Google Meet will be for interaction and questions. If you are unable to join the session, it will be recorded and a link will be posted here when the recording is available.
  • Exams will still be held more-or-less as scheduled, although I am still working out the details.
  • Instead of office hours, I will be happy to answer questions at any time by email or to set up an appointment for a phone call or video chat (Google Meet, Hangout, Skype, or something else that works for you).

Test video recorded with Google Meet.

Here are the topics planned for the rest of the semester:

  • 3/30-4/3 Trees, Traversals, Graphs, Graph Traversals
  • 4/6-4/10 Languages, Regular Expressions, Finite-State Automata
  • 4/13-4/17 Exam 2, Friday April 17
  • 4/20-4/24 Sequential Circuits and State Machines
  • 4/27-5/1 Grammars, Parsing, Pushdown Automata
  • 5/4-5/6 Turing Machines, Computability, Exam Review
  • Saturday 5/9 (Section A) or Monday 5/11 (Section B) Final Exam

item.title: MapReduce
item.description: No reading for today. We will talk about the map and reduce functions on lists, and how they made Google what it is today.
item.content:encoded:
No reading for today. We will talk about the map and reduce functions on lists, and how they made Google what it is today.

For reference, here are the definitions of map and reduce developed in class (this version of reduce is often called foldLeft):

let rec map = (f, aList) => {
  switch (aList) {
  | [] => []
  | [head, ...tail] => [f(head), ...map(f, tail)]
  }
};

let rec reduce = (g, init, aList) => {
  switch (aList) {
  | [] => init
  | [head, ...tail] => reduce(g, g(init, head), tail)
  }
};

map(n => {2 * n}, [1, 2, 3, 4]);
reduce((+), 0, [1, 2, 3, 4]);
reduce((*), 1, [1, 2, 3, 4]);
reduce((summary, n) => {summary ++ "," ++ string_of_int(n)}, "", [1, 2, 3, 4]);
reduce((+), 0, map(n => {2 * n}, [1, 2, 3, 4]));

item.content:encoded: Finish reading Types in Functional Programming. Look at Exercises 1, 2, 3, and 5, to discuss in class.

item.title: Types and Functional Programming

item.content:encoded: Read about Types in Functional Programming. I am still writing this section, so there are no exercises to look at yet.

item.title: Functions and Functional Programming
item.description: Read about Functions and an Introduction to Functional Programming,
item.content:encoded: Read about Functions and an Introduction to Functional Programming, and look at exercises 1, 2, and 5 (to discuss in class).

item.title: Recursion and Induction
item.description: Read about Recursion,
item.content:encoded:
Read about Recursion, and look at exercises 3, 4, 7, 8, and 10 (to discuss in class).

Here is the proof that I started last Friday in class, and didn't complete:

Theorem:
$\exists x\forall yP(x, y)\vdash\forall y\exists xP(x, y)$

Proof: $$ \begin{array}{ll} \ell_1: \exists x\forall yP(x, y) & \text{premise}\ \ell_2: \text{fresh}\ x_0, \forall yP(x_0, y)\Rightarrow{\ \quad\ell_3: \text{fresh}\ y_0\Rightarrow{\ \quad\quad\ell_4: P(x_0, y_0) & \forall E\ \ell_2, y_0\ \quad\quad\ell_5: \exists xP(x, y_0) & \exists I\ \ell_4, x_0\ \quad}\ \quad\ell_6: \forall y\exists xP(x, y) & \forall I\ \ell_3\ }\ \ell_7: \forall y\exists xP(x, y) & \exists E\ \ell_1, \ell_2 \end{array} $$

In words, since we start by assuming an existential, we can suppose ($\ell2$) that $x_0$ is the (fresh) name of an $x$ that makes $\forall yP(x_0, y)$ true. Now, to prove a universal quantifier, we need to introduce _another fresh variable, $y_0$; if we can show $\exists xP(x, y_0)$ without any other conditions on $y_0$, then we can reach our desired conclusion. But since we know (within the subproof starting at $\ell_2$) that $P(x_0, y)$ holds for all $y$, we might as well choose $y$ to be $y_0$, at $\ell_4$. Now we have some particular $x_0$ and $y_0$ making $P$ true, so we can conclude $\exists xP(x, y_0)$ at $\ell_5$. This finishes what we needed for the $\forall I$ step at $\ell_6$, and the proof concludes with the application of $\exists E$ that we set up at the beginning.

item.content:encoded: Skim the sections on set concepts and algebra (these two sections should be mostly review of material you should have seen before, with emphasis on the connection to propositional logic). item.content:encoded:

Here is a tentative schedule of events for the semester:

  • Wednesday, March 4: Exam 1
  • Friday, March 13: No class (SIGCSE conference)
  • Friday, March 20: Last day to withdraw with a W
  • Monday, March 23–Friday, March 27: Spring Break
